Award.AwardTitle: High Spatial Resolution Cold and Thermal Neutron Imaging Sensor

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to investigate boron carbide diode-based sensors applied to high spatial
resolution neutron imagers. The approach is to experimentally and theoretically investigate the
operational parameters and spatial resolution enhancement techniques required for this purpose. The
four spatial resolution enhancement techniques to be investigated include threshold discrimination,
density gradient, fast logic, and columnar sensor medium techniques. Each of these enhancement
techniques will be investigated for feasibility and effectiveness. Boron carbide diode sensors will also be
characterized experimentally with respect to related operational parameters for these spatial resolution
enhancement techniques. The combination of these results will provide a basis for the development of a
state-of-the-art neutron imager. The boron carbide will also be tested through direct coupling with Timepix
QTPX-262k to test its functionality and improvement of current state of the art techniques utilizing
established front end electronics and signal processing methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research was to investigate the feasibility of boron carbide cold/thermal neutron imaging sensors. Boron carbide, B4C, has a very high cold/thermal neutron absorption efficiency per unit length, due to the 3842 barn microscopic cross section of 10B. The potential benefit of the development of this kind of neutron imager is in its semiconducting nature, which potentially enables excellent timing with a large dynamic range and a simultaneous high detection efficiency and spatial resolution. Typically, one or more of these metrics is inversely proportional to other metrics, so the potential to maximize each metric yields its wide application at neutron imaging facilities around the world. Further, its semiconducting nature yields a low-power, compact design, which lends itself to other neutron detection applications, such as reactor monitoring sensors and hand-held sensors for nuclear security.

Within the scope of the project, we built and utilized a custom hot filament chemical vapor deposition system for boron carbide growth. Numerous boron carbide films were grown, and iterative optimization was pursued with particular focus on enhancing their semiconducting properties. Boron carbide films were grown on silicon substrates, and the resistivity of the films was found to be much higher than that of the silicon substrate. The Hall mobility of grown substrates was ~20 cm2/Vs, and all films were appropriately identified as p-type. Computational investigation determined the properties of the heterojunction, the ideal carrier concentration in the p-type boron carbide film and n-type silicon substrate, the necessary applied bias to fully deplete the sensor, and the necessary thickness to achieve a given neutron absorption efficiency. Further, the investigation of a repeating array of a columnar structure of boron carbide, separated by insulating silicon oxide, was found to have an inter-pixel capacitance on the order of 10 aF. The products of the research were two Master of Science degrees and three conference presentations.
